en.task-template-builder-how-to-survey:
Instructions for Survey:
  • Add a question (button "Add Question")
  • Choose the type of question (dropdown menu)
  • Enter the question and the possible answers
  • Set optionality (use "Required" switch)
  • Add more answers if necessary (button "Add Answer")
  • Add more questions if necessary (button "Add Question")
  • If necessary, add "Condition" between questions
en.task-template-builder-how-to-condition:
Example for Condition:

Question 1: Are the dogs in the image?
  • Answer 1: Yes
  • Answer 2: No
  • Answer 3: I can't say
Question 2: How many dogs in the image?

Condition: Question 2 will be visible only if the answer to Question 1 is "Yes".
When on Question 2, click on "Condition", then select Question 1 as conditional question and select "Yes" as conditional answer.
en.task-template-builder-how-to-map-setting:
Instructions for Map Settings:
  • Write the prompt or question.
  • Enter the coordinates (lat,lon) for the center of displayed map.
  • You can also define the default map zoom.
  • Choose the contributor’s interaction(s) with the map: draw an area and/or put a marker (define how many markers).

en.home-solution-kit-cards: The Citizen Science Center Zurich is developing a set of tools that make it easy for scientists and citizens to engage with Citizens Science projects.
en.solution-kit-discover-description: Browse the projects created by scientists and citizens to answer questions in science and society, and contribute your own brain power!
en.solution-kit-cslogger-description: Engage people in contributing all sorts of digital data for scientific quests by creating a ready to use data collection app for smartphones.
en.solution-kit-pb-description: If the analysis of your data (images, videos, documents, ...) can profit of people’s unique skills and wisdom, build a project for them!
en.cslogger-introduction:
Citizen Science data collection project engage people in crowdsourcing tasks, contributing data in multiple form, such a text (survey answers), images, video, audio, geolocation, etc.

The Citizen Science Logger allows you to create such projects in the form of a smartphone App (iOS and Android). The creation happens via a web interface, with a simple step-by-step process.
en.cslogger-team-content:
The CS LOGGER is based on MindLogger, a web/mobile platform that makes it easy for anyone to build a smartphone app for all sorts of media collection (i.e. surveys, digital diaries, images, …). MindLogger is a development of the Child Mind Institute (CMI) in New York. Originally designed for mental health applications, it features a vast and powerful array of activities such as surveys, quizzes, digital diaries, and cognitive tasks. On top of these, more traditional and domain-generic Citizen Science activities are allowed, including the collection of geo-located images, video, and audio.

The adaptation of MindLogger to become a “CS Logger” is a joint effort of the ETH Library Lab, CMI, CRI, under the direction of the CS Center Zurich. The work in Zurich has been partially supported by EU CROWD4SDG.
en.cslogger-create-app-key-terms-example-0:
Before starting, learn about some key terms used in the interface:

  • APPLET: The platform uses the term Applet instead of App. Applet refers to small applications, performing one or a few simple functions. So, you will be creating Applets.
  • ACTIVITY: Applets are made of activities, such as filling a survey, recording a video, and other digital tasks. So, you will be adding activities to your Applet.
  • ITEMS: Each activity is made of one or more item(s).
  • SCREENS: Each item includes one or more screens (these are the screens on your smartphone).

For details and Q&A have a look of the MindLogger Admin Guide https://mindlogger.org/guides/admin-guide.html

Example:
To further clarify the terms and their use, and illustrate the process, we will use this example: You are creating an applet to collect geo-located images of stray dogs. For each image, you would like your contributors to add their account of the dog attitude.
en.cslogger-create-app-build-applet-0:
Go to admin.mindlogger.org

Login or create an account.
en.cslogger-create-app-build-applet-1:
For the first time you will see the welcome message.

Please click on the “CLICK HERE” button and select “Build an applet”.
en.cslogger-create-app-build-applet-2:
Enter your applet name and description.
You can add more details in the about page, an image, and you have the choice of three themes.

Example:
Applet Name: Stray dogs (test)
Description: By using this App you provide information about the stray dogs you meet in your whereabouts. This will help...
en.cslogger-create-app-add-activities-0:
Click “ADD ACTIVITY” to add the first activity to your project. Add your activity name and description.

Note: For some applications, you may want to add more activities. For example, if your Applet includes answering questions at different times of the day, you will have a “Morning Questionnaire” and a “Evening Questionnaire”.

Example:
The first activity for your contributors is to take a geo-located photo of the dog.
Name: Geo-located Photo
Description: Take a geo-located photo of a dog.
en.cslogger-create-app-add-activities-1:
Add the first item to your activity by clicking the “ADD ITEM” button and select “Blank item”.

An item is composed of one or more screens. The first screen will be added.
Click on to edit it.
en.cslogger-create-app-design-screens-first:
Fill the details for your Screen 1.

  • You can add a header image to this screen.
  • Use the text creator to enter your question/instruction.
  • Choose the input type.
  • Set additional options if necessary.

Example:
The first screen of the app will ask the user to allow geo-location service in the smartphone.
Text Creator: Please allow the app to access your phone location services.
Input Type: geolocation

Add a second item, click on icon to edit, and fill the details for your Screen 2. In this screen, the user has to take a photo.

Example:
The second screen of the app will ask the user to take a picture of the target dog.
Text Creator: Please take a picture of the dog. Don’t get too close and be careful not to put yourself in danger!
Input Type: photo
en.cslogger-create-app-design-screens-secon:
Add a third item, click on icon to edit, and fill the details for your Screen 3. In this screen, the user has to answer a dropdown type question.

Example:
The third screen of the app will ask the user to choose the perceived dog's attitude.

  • Text Creator: How would you describe the attitude of the dog?
  • Input Type: radio
  • Options:
    • Friendly
    • Scared
    • Aggressive
    • Other

Add a fourth item, click on icon to edit, and fill the details for your Screen 4. This screen will be shown only if the user selects “Other” in the previous question.

Example:
The fourth screen of the app will ask the user which other option in for dog's attitude.

  • Text Creator: You chose "Other", how would you describe the dog's attitude?
  • Input Type: text

As you added an open option on the Screen 3, this requires knowing which other option the user refers to. Thus add a Conditional Logic.

Example:
Click on the “Conditional Logic” button at the top of the page.
Click on the “ADD CONDITIONAL” button. Insert your condition: Only if Screen 3 is equal to “Other”, then show Screen 4.
en.cslogger-create-app-save-overview-0:
When the applet edition is finished, please save it by clicking the “Save to Dashboard” button.

It’s required to ingress a password to protect the applet. Please save it carefully.

You will receive an email that confirms the applet creation.
en.cslogger-create-app-save-overview-1: Go back to your dashboard (click on “MindLogger Dashboard” on top of page) and you will see the Applet just created together with the previously created ones.
en.cslogger-share-app-settings-privacy-0:
It’s now time to invite the participants! You have two choices:

  • You can keep your Applet private and only invite specific participants to use it. In this case you need each users’ email. You can also assign to each invitee different roles.
  • You can generate a public link so that anybody with the link can use your Applet. You can also choose if you want your users to create an account or contribute anonymously.
en.cslogger-share-app-settings-privacy-1:
Go to admin.mindlogger.org and login at your account.

On your dashboard, you can see the list of applets created. For sharing the desired applet is required send invitations.
You can manage your invitations clicking on the “View Users”.

Example:
On the Stray Dogs (Test) applet click on button.
en.cslogger-share-app-invite-participants-0:
On invitation tab you can find the following sections:

  • Pending Invitations
    List of invitations already sent to users and pending to be accepted.
  • Create Invitation
    Create a new invitation and send it to the user’s email.
  • Public Link
    Set the user contribution as public, therefore it is not required to create an invitation.

Example:
Click on the “GENERATE” button in the Public Link section.
en.cslogger-share-app-invite-participants-1:
For a public contribution, it is possible to do it anonymously or identifiable, for which it is necessary to create an account on mindlogger or not respectively.

Example:
Click on “No”.
en.cslogger-share-app-invite-participants-2:
Now is possible to share the assessment link for inviting participants to contribute. Please copy and send to participants or publishing somewhere.

Example:
Click copy icon on the right side, and paste in email to your friends.
en.cslogger-share-app-install-applet-0: For a successful user contribution, all participants need to download the MindLogger app either from the app store for iOS or google play for Android. This step is required only for the first time, just before the first participation. All subsequent contributions, and contributions to new projects will not need this step.
en.cslogger-share-app-install-applet-2: Once the app is installed on the device, all the participants need to do is click on the link provided by the project organizers (see above) and follow instructions on app.
en.cslogger-integration-pb-introduction-0:
After the crowdsourcing process is performed with the CS Logger app, it is necessary to analyze the information collected in order to contribute to the results of any ongoing research project. For this, it is possible to integrate the information collected in CS Logger into Project Builder and build typical survey tools based on that information.

Example:
Let’s keep our Stray Dogs app as an example (see steps above). When people have contributed enough images of dogs for your study, you want people to look at the images and describe the dog in detail and say if they agree with the attitude as reported by the image collector.
en.cslogger-integration-pb-export-data-0:
Go to admin.mindlogger.org and login at your account.

On your dashboard, you can see the list of applets created. Please click on the applet name to access the management and settings section.

Example:
Click on “Stray dogs (test)”
en.cslogger-integration-pb-export-data-1:
Here it is possible to perform the following actions by clicking on the buttons located in the top bar:

  • View and manage users and invitations
  • View general calendar
  • Edit the applet
  • Export data contributed for participants
  • Duplicate applet
  • Delete applet

Example:
Click on Export Data, ingress the password of the applet and click on “SUBMIT”
en.cslogger-integration-pb-export-data-2:
After downloading, there will be two files:

  • report.csv: contains the data collected by the applet
  • media-responses-xxxxx.zip: contains the multimedia collected by the applet

Please unzip the compressed file before continuing with the next steps.
en.cslogger-integration-pb-create-project: Create a project with CS PB
en.cslogger-integration-pb-create-project-0:
For create a project based on the collected data by the applet using CS Logger, please click on the button and follow the instructions (You must be logged in):

Create Project

If you need help to create your project click on How to Create Project.
en.cspb-introduction:
Citizen Science projects for the analysis of digital data engage people in complex tasks such as image analysis, pattern recognition, text transcription, mapping, etc. Such tasks are performed via a web interface on existing digital data.

The Citizen Science Project Builder is a web-based tool that allows you to create and run data-analysis projects with a simple step-by-step process.

The CS Project Builder is a joint effort of the Citizen Cyberlab at University of Geneva and the Citizen Science Center Zurich. The development work has been partially supported by EU CROWD4SDG.
en.cspb-create-project-card-0:
The Project Builder supports projects where volunteer contributors can analyse or enrich existing data. In particular, it allows to:

  • Classify or describe large sets of images or text (ie. identify images, count objects, describe scenes) and social media content (tweets).
  • Classify or describe sounds and video clips.
  • Work on PDF documents (transcribe, translate, describe).
  • Geo-code images or tweets, ie. mark their location on a map (note: this task requires some coding skills!).

Before starting, it is required to login into your Project Builder account or to register a new account if you don't have one so far.

This is possible by clicking on the LOGIN button at the top right of this screen.
en.cspb-create-project-card-1:
Clicking on your username, located at the top right of the screen, you can select “Create a project”. And follow the next instructions:

  • Choose a nice and catchy title, which describes your project.
  • Add a short description (120 characters).
  • Upload from your computer an image to represent the project (<1Mb).
en.cspb-create-project-overview-0:
You’re now asked to enter additional text to explain your project in simple terms (each part 800 characters max. long):

  • WHAT & WHY what is the purpose of your project, and why is it is important;
  • HOW your volunteers can contribute, and how their contributions will be used;
  • WHO is behind the project;
  • WHO you are inviting to contribute to the project;
  • ADDITIONAL LINKS - including links to your website, social media, and details on how contributors can contact or follow you.

At this point, you have now created the homepage of your project.

Note: If you decide to leave the platform now, you will find the draft of your project in your profile, “Draft Projects” section.
en.cspb-create-project-type-0:
Select the kind of data you want to work with. Options include:

  • Images (*.jpg, *.png, *.gif, *.svg or *.bmp)
  • Videos (*.avi, *.mp4, *.3gp or *.mpeg)
  • Audios (*.mp3, *.wav or *.aac)
  • Documents (.pdf)
  • Tweets (@account or #hashtag)
  • CSLogger (Integration with mobile app)

Example:
Create a project based on images, therefore click on “Images”
en.cspb-create-project-type-1:
Select the task you would like your contributors to perform. You can choose:

  • Survey format, for tasks such as classification, description, and counting.
  • Survey plus geolocation, if the task also includes geolocation on a map (for example identify a landmark in an image and locate it on a city).

Example:
A simple survey is enough, therefore click on “Survey”
en.cspb-create-project-design-0:
Design your survey, including many options of questions and answers, or text fields.
In particular:

  • Add a question (button "Add Question")
  • Choose the type of question (dropdown menu)
  • Enter the question and the possible answers
  • Set optionality (use "Required" switch)
  • Add more answers if necessary (button "Add Answer")
  • Add more questions if necessary (button "Add Question")
en.cspb-create-project-design-1:
Design a geo-based survey, ingressing the following information and settings:

  • Question for user instruction
  • Map center: Default location for centering map
  • Map zoom: Default map zoom between 1 and 18
  • Draw area: allows user draw an area on map
  • Markers: allows user to put markers on map

Additionally you can add a survey as mentioned above.
en.cspb-create-project-design-2:
It’s also possible to add conditions between questions, as follow:

Example for Condition:

Question 1 (single choice): Do you know the breed of the dog?
  • Answer 1: Yes
  • Answer 2: No
  • Answer 3: I can't say
Question 2 (short answer): What is the breed of the dog?

Condition: Question 2 will be visible only if the answer to Question 1 is "Yes".
When on Question 2, click on "Condition", then select Question 1 as conditional question and select "Yes" as conditional answer.
en.cspb-create-project-source-0:
It’s time to import your source files (images, videos, sounds, ...). The possible data sources include: Dropbox, Flickr, Amazon S3 buckets or csv file. There are particular cases for Twitter or CSLoger datasources.

You will also be able to add additional files later from the “project overview” page when the project was already created.

Note: The Project Builder is NOT copying your file, it is linking to them. So make sure they stay in the original location for the duration of the project.

Make sure you are authorized to use the data, ie. use free licensed files (Creative Commons or alike), your own files, or copyright files that you are authorized to use.

Example:
We have a list of public images in csv format, then click on “csv File”, for uploading it.
en.cspb-create-project-source-1:
Finally, before creating the project, you can check the summary. Since this point is possible to come back using the navigation routes on the top-left section and to edit whatever you consider.

Click on “CREATE!” button. To finalize the process.
en.cspb-integration-cslogger-project-type-0:
For the particular case of CSLogger project type, please click on the “CSLogger” button Select your project type as is presented on the image.

Note: The previous steps to this are similar regardless of the project type. Please check the “How to create a project” section.
en.cspb-integration-cslogger-project-type-1: CSLogger just allows the creation of a simple survey for your task protocol. Please click on “Survey”.
en.cspb-integration-cslogger-project-source:
Import your data collected by the crowdsourcing process done with the CSLogger applet already downloaded. The required files are:

  • Data file: report.csv file with metadata and responses.
  • Media files: unzipped multimedia files.

Note: if you have not yet downloaded the data, please go to admin.mindlogger.org, and follow the instructions on tools/cslogger Integration with CS Project Builder section.
en.cspb-test-and-publish-project-0:
Each project has its own page, which has two important sections. In the upper section you can find the following buttons:

  • MODIFY DRAFT: allows you to edit the current version of the project.
  • TEST IT!: by clicking on this button you can test the version that the users will see.
  • GET SHAREABLE LINK: creates a temporary link for you to share with others.
  • SUBMIT FOR PUBLICATION: send to Citizen Science Center a request to be published.

Example:
Click on “TEST IT!” button to check your project creation.
en.cspb-test-and-publish-project-1:
Few things before you go public:

  • Double check the Criteria for publication on the top of this page and make sure the project complies.
  • Please remember “GET A SHARABLE LINK” allows you to share your draft with co-workers (don’t use this link for running the project there results won’t be saved).

Ready?... “SUBMIT FOR PUBLICATION”
We will make sure your project adheres to our criteria and works, and get back to you within a few hours with approval or - if need be - additional requests.
en.cspb-test-and-publish-project-settings-0:
From the different tabs of your project’s dashboard, you access:

  • Info: overview (modify) the current description of the project.
  • Statistics overview the current statistics for your projects when are published.
  • Tasks: you can do multiple actions:
    • Import Tasks - import more source files via the provided importer
    • Task Presenter - change the protocol of your tasks.
      Note: This require coding skills.
    • Browse - check the status of each task after published.
    • Export Tasks - export tasks to JSON, CSV, or a CKAN server.
    • Task Settings - configure all aspects of tasks, including scheduler, priority, and redundancy. You can also delete tasks.
  • Settings: edit the description of the project, select project category, allow anonymous contribution.
en.about-question-1: What is the Citizen Science Project Builder?
en.about-answer-1: The Citizen Science Project Builder is a web-based tool that allows researchers, students, and all members of the public to create and run Citizen Science Projects.
en.about-question-2: What is a Citizen Science project?
en.about-answer-2: In Citizen Science projects, volunteer contributors (“citizens”) and scientists work together to produce scientific knowledge. Projects may take many different forms, from classifying images of snakes to transcribing handwritten German dialect, from collecting samples of water to taking pictures of insects and plants. If you want to learn more about Citizen Science (including an extensive list of existing projects) {link1} is a good starting point.
en.about-question-3: Which kind of projects can be created in the CS Project Builder?
en.about-answer-3: In its initial version, the CS Project Builder allows users to perform complex data classification tasks. It supports projects where contributors can analyze or enrich existing data, typically large sets of images or texts (ie. satellite pictures, social media posts, etc.), as well as other media formats such as videos, audios, and scanned documents. Next step, the web-based tool will be integrated with a data collection (smartphone-based) tool. .
en.about-question-4: What is the aim of the CS Project Builder?
en.about-answer-4: The CS Project Builder facilitates the implementation of CS projects by providing an interface that requires limited technical knowledge, and ideally little or no coding skills. Its aim is to facilitate the co-creation of Citizen Science projects by starting with the implementation of simple pilots.
en.about-answer-5: Anybody with an idea for a data classification project can implement it here, as long as it complies with the platform criteria {criteria}. Next step is to build around it an initial community of contributors (colleagues, friends, family, and more!) that will allow to test its scope, form, and potentials. By involving all contributors in the co-creation process, a lot can be learned about research questions, process, data, and mutual benefits, before deciding to spend more resources in a full-fledged implementation (ie. developing a project with a unique graphic style, dedicated features, etc. For more info on this option, please contact us).
en.about-answer-6: The web interface for the CS Project Builder is inspired by the now discontinued Crowdcrafting platform. Its implementation is based on the open source crowdsourcing framework {pybossa}. The code is publicly available under the ‘CitizenScienceCenter’ organisation on {csgit}.
en.about-criteria-label1: Anybody can create a project in the platform, as long it obeys to the following criteria:
en.about-criteria-list1: The project’s topic and goals have clear scientific and/or social interest.
en.about-criteria-list2: The project objectives and desired outcomes are communicated in the project description in an accessible and comprehensible manner.
en.about-criteria-list3: The objectives of the project are impossible – or very hard - to achieve without the contribution of the citizens.
en.about-criteria-list4: The project is open for all volunteer contributors to participate.
en.about-criteria-list5: An easy way to communicate with the project organizer is available for feedback and discussions.
en.about-criteria-list6: The content of the project does not facilitate illegal acts and does not cause offense to any audience (see terms and conditions for details).
en.about-criteria-list7: The project’s goals (quantity of necessary data, coverage, required number of participants) are reasonable and achievable within a defined timeframe.
en.about-criteria-list8: Ethical aspects are considered (e.g. diversity, inclusion, gender equality) and permission of the UZH/ETH Ethical Commission is previously requested and obtained when necessary.
en.about-criteria-list9: Data generated by the project follows the EC principle 'as open as possible, as closed as necessary', which focuses encouraging as few restrictions as possible, while at the same time protecting sensitive data from inappropriate access.
en.about-criteria-list10: The results of the project are published in an open-access format, provided there are no legitimate, legal, or ethical arguments against doing so.

de.home-solution-kit-cards: The Citizen Science Center Zurich is developing a set of tools that make it easy for scientists and citizens to engage with Citizens Science projects.
de.solution-kit-discover-description: Browse the projects created by scientists and citizens to answer questions in science and society, and contribute your own brain power!
de.solution-kit-cslogger-description: Engage people in contributing all sorts of digital data for scientific quests by creating a ready to use data collection app for smartphones.
de.solution-kit-pb-description: If the analysis of your data (images, videos, documents, ...) can profit of people’s unique skills and wisdom, build a project for them!
de.cslogger-introduction:
Citizen Science data-collection projects engage people in contributing multiple form of digital data, such a text (survey answers), images, video, audio, geolocation, etc.

The Citizen Science Logger allows you to create such projects in the form of a smartphone App (iOS and Android). The creation happens via a web interface, with a simple step-by-step process.
de.cslogger-team-content:
The CS LOGGER is based on MindLogger, a web/mobile platform that makes it easy for anyone to build a smartphone app for all sorts of media collection (i.e. surveys, digital diaries, images, …). MindLogger is a development of the Child Mind Institute (CMI) in New York. Originally designed for mental health applications, it features a vast and powerful array of activities such as surveys, quizzes, digital diaries, and cognitive tasks. On top of these, more traditional and domain-generic Citizen Science activities are allowed, including the collection of geo-located images, video, and audio.

The adaptation of MindLogger to become a “CS Logger” is a joint effort of the ETH Library Lab, CMI, CRI, under the direction of the CS Center Zurich. The work in Zurich has been partially supported by EU CROWD4SDG.
de.cslogger-create-app-key-terms-example-0:
Before starting, learn about some key terms used in the interface:

  • APPLET: The platform uses the term Applet instead of App. Applet refers to small applications, performing one or a few simple functions. So, you will be creating Applets.
  • ACTIVITY: Applets are made of activities, such as filling a survey, recording a video, and other digital tasks. So, you will be adding activities to your Applet.
  • ITEMS: Each activity is made of one or more item(s).
  • SCREENS: Each item includes one or more screens (these are the screens on your smartphone).

For details and Q&A have a look of the MindLogger Admin Guide https://mindlogger.org/guides/admin-guide.html

Example:
To further clarify the terms and their use, and illustrate the process, we will use this example: You are creating an applet to collect geo-located images of stray dogs. For each image, you would like your contributors to add their account of the dog attitude.
de.cslogger-create-app-build-applet-0:
Go to admin.mindlogger.org

Login or create an account.
de.cslogger-create-app-build-applet-1:
For the first time you will see the welcome message.

Please click on the “CLICK HERE” button and select “Build an applet”.
de.cslogger-create-app-build-applet-2:
Enter your applet name and description.
You can add more details in the about page, an image, and you have the choice of three themes.

Example:
Applet Name: Stray dogs (test)
Description: By using this App you provide information about the stray dogs you meet in your whereabouts. This will help...
de.cslogger-create-app-add-activities-0:
Click “ADD ACTIVITY” to add the first activity to your project. Add your activity name and description.

Note: For some applications, you may want to add more activities. For example, if your Applet includes answering questions at different times of the day, you will have a “Morning Questionnaire” and a “Evening Questionnaire”.

Example:
The first activity for your contributors is to take a geo-located photo of the dog.
Name: Geo-located Photo
Description: Take a geo-located photo of a dog.
de.cslogger-create-app-add-activities-1:
Add the first item to your activity by clicking the “ADD ITEM” button and select “Blank item”.

An item is composed of one or more screens. The first screen will be added.
Click on to edit it.
de.cslogger-create-app-design-screens-first:
Fill the details for your Screen 1.

  • You can add a header image to this screen.
  • Use the text creator to enter your question/instruction.
  • Choose the input type.
  • Set additional options if necessary.

Example:
The first screen of the app will ask the user to allow geo-location service in the smartphone.
Text Creator: Please allow the app to access your phone location services.
Input Type: geolocation

Add a second item, click on icon to edit, and fill the details for your Screen 2. In this screen, the user has to take a photo.

Example:
The second screen of the app will ask the user to take a picture of the target dog.
Text Creator: Please take a picture of the dog. Don’t get too close and be careful not to put yourself in danger!
Input Type: photo
de.cslogger-create-app-design-screens-secon:
Add a third item, click on icon to edit, and fill the details for your Screen 3. In this screen, the user has to answer a dropdown type question.

Example:
The third screen of the app will ask the user to choose the perceived dog's attitude.

  • Text Creator: How would you describe the attitude of the dog?
  • Input Type: radio
  • Options:
    • Friendly
    • Scared
    • Aggressive
    • Other

Add a fourth item, click on icon to edit, and fill the details for your Screen 4. This screen will be shown only if the user selects “Other” in the previous question.

Example:
The fourth screen of the app will ask the user which other option in for dog's attitude.

  • Text Creator: You chose "Other", how would you describe the dog's attitude?
  • Input Type: text

As you added an open option on the Screen 3, this requires knowing which other option the user refers to. Thus add a Conditional Logic.

Example:
Click on the “Conditional Logic” button at the top of the page.
Click on the “ADD CONDITIONAL” button. Insert your condition: Only if Screen 3 is equal to “Other”, then show Screen 4.
de.cslogger-create-app-save-overview-0:
When the applet edition is finished, please save it by clicking the “Save to Dashboard” button.

It’s required to ingress a password to protect the applet. Please save it carefully.

You will receive an email that confirms the applet creation.
de.cslogger-create-app-save-overview-1: Go back to your dashboard (click on “MindLogger Dashboard” on top of page) and you will see the Applet just created together with the previously created ones.
de.cslogger-share-app-settings-privacy-0:
It’s now time to invite the participants! You have two choices:

  • You can keep your Applet private and only invite specific participants to use it. In this case you need each users’ email. You can also assign to each invitee different roles.
  • You can generate a public link so that anybody with the link can use your Applet. You can also choose if you want your users to create an account or contribute anonymously.
de.cslogger-share-app-settings-privacy-1:
Go to admin.mindlogger.org and login at your account.

On your dashboard, you can see the list of applets created. For sharing the desired applet is required send invitations.
You can manage your invitations clicking on the “View Users”.

Example:
On the Stray Dogs (Test) applet click on button.
de.cslogger-share-app-invite-participants-0:
On invitation tab you can find the following sections:

  • Pending Invitations
    List of invitations already sent to users and pending to be accepted.
  • Create Invitation
    Create a new invitation and send it to the user’s email.
  • Public Link
    Set the user contribution as public, therefore it is not required to create an invitation.

Example:
Click on the “GENERATE” button in the Public Link section.
de.cslogger-share-app-invite-participants-1:
For a public contribution, it is possible to do it anonymously or identifiable, for which it is necessary to create an account on mindlogger or not respectively.

Example:
Click on “No”.
de.cslogger-share-app-invite-participants-2:
Now is possible to share the assessment link for inviting participants to contribute. Please copy and send to participants or publishing somewhere.

Example:
Click copy icon on the right side, and paste in email to your friends.
de.cslogger-share-app-install-applet-0: For a successful user contribution, all participants need to download the MindLogger app either from the app store for iOS or google play for Android. This step is required only for the first time, just before the first participation. All subsequent contributions, and contributions to new projects will not need this step.
de.cslogger-share-app-install-applet-2: Once the app is installed on the device, all the participants need to do is click on the link provided by the project organizers (see above) and follow instructions on app.
de.cslogger-integration-pb-introduction-0:
After the crowdsourcing process is performed with the CS Logger app, it is necessary to analyze the information collected in order to contribute to the results of any ongoing research project. For this, it is possible to integrate the information collected in CS Logger into Project Builder and build typical survey tools based on that information.

Example:
Let’s keep our Stray Dogs app as an example (see steps above). When people have contributed enough images of dogs for your study, you want people to look at the images and describe the dog in detail and say if they agree with the attitude as reported by the image collector.
de.cslogger-integration-pb-export-data-0:
Go to admin.mindlogger.org and login at your account.

On your dashboard, you can see the list of applets created. Please click on the applet name to access the management and settings section.

Example:
Click on “Stray dogs (test)”
de.cslogger-integration-pb-export-data-1:
Here it is possible to perform the following actions by clicking on the buttons located in the top bar:

  • View and manage users and invitations
  • View general calendar
  • Edit the applet
  • Export data contributed for participants
  • Duplicate applet
  • Delete applet

Example:
Click on Export Data, ingress the password of the applet and click on “SUBMIT”
de.cslogger-integration-pb-export-data-2:
After downloading, there will be two files:

  • report.csv: contains the data collected by the applet
  • media-responses-xxxxx.zip: contains the multimedia collected by the applet

Please unzip the compressed file before continuing with the next steps.
de.cslogger-integration-pb-create-project: Create a project with CS PB
de.cslogger-integration-pb-create-project-0:
For create a project based on the collected data by the applet using CS Logger, please click on the button and follow the instructions (You must be logged in):

Create Project

If you need help to create your project click on How to Create Project
de.cspb-introduction:
Citizen Science projects for the analysis of digital data engage people in complex tasks such as image analysis, pattern recognition, text transcription, mapping, etc. Such tasks are performed via a web interface on existing digital data.

The Citizen Science Project Builder is a web-based tool that allows you to create and run data-analysis projects with a simple step-by-step process.

The CS Project Builder is a joint effort of the Citizen Cyberlab at University of Geneva and the Citizen Science Center Zurich. The development work has been partially supported by EU CROWD4SDG.
de.cspb-create-project-card-0:
The Project Builder supports projects where volunteer contributors can analyse or enrich existing data. In particular, it allows to:

  • Classify or describe large sets of images or text (ie. identify images, count objects, describe scenes) and social media content (tweets).
  • Classify or describe sounds and video clips.
  • Work on PDF documents (transcribe, translate, describe).
  • Geo-code images or tweets, ie. mark their location on a map (note: this task requires some coding skills!).

Before starting, it is required to login into your Project Builder account or to register a new account if you don't have one so far.

This is possible by clicking on the LOGIN button at the top right of this screen.
de.cspb-create-project-card-1:
Clicking on your username, located at the top right of the screen, you can select “Create a project”. And follow the next instructions:

  • Choose a nice and catchy title, which describes your project.
  • Add a short description (120 characters).
  • Upload from your computer an image to represent the project (<1Mb).
de.cspb-create-project-overview-0:
You’re now asked to enter additional text to explain your project in simple terms (each part 800 characters max. long):

  • WHAT & WHY what is the purpose of your project, and why is it is important;
  • HOW your volunteers can contribute, and how their contributions will be used;
  • WHO is behind the project;
  • WHO you are inviting to contribute to the project;
  • ADDITIONAL LINKS - including links to your website, social media, and details on how contributors can contact or follow you.

At this point, you have now created the homepage of your project.

Note: If you decide to leave the platform now, you will find the draft of your project in your profile, “Draft Projects” section.
de.cspb-create-project-type-0:
Select the kind of data you want to work with. Options include:

  • Images (*.jpg, *.png, *.gif, *.svg or *.bmp)
  • Videos (*.avi, *.mp4, *.3gp or *.mpeg)
  • Audios (*.mp3, *.wav or *.aac)
  • Documents (.pdf)
  • Tweets (@account or #hashtag)
  • CSLogger (Integration with mobile app)

Example:
Create a project based on images, therefore click on “Images”
de.cspb-create-project-type-1:
Select the task you would like your contributors to perform. You can choose:

  • Survey format, for tasks such as classification, description, and counting.
  • Survey plus geolocation, if the task also includes geolocation on a map (for example identify a landmark in an image and locate it on a city).

Example:
A simple survey is enough, therefore click on “Survey”
de.cspb-create-project-design-0:
Design your survey, including many options of questions and answers, or text fields.
In particular:

  • Add a question (button "Add Question")
  • Choose the type of question (dropdown menu)
  • Enter the question and the possible answers
  • Set optionality (use "Required" switch)
  • Add more answers if necessary (button "Add Answer")
  • Add more questions if necessary (button "Add Question")
de.cspb-create-project-design-1:
Design a geo-based survey, ingressing the following information and settings:

  • Question for user instruction
  • Map center: Default location for centering map
  • Map zoom: Default map zoom between 1 and 18
  • Draw area: allows user draw an area on map
  • Markers: allows user to put markers on map

Additionally you can add a survey as mentioned above.
de.cspb-create-project-design-2:
It’s also possible to add conditions between questions, as follow:

Example for Condition:

Question 1 (single choice): Do you know the breed of the dog?
  • Answer 1: Yes
  • Answer 2: No
  • Answer 3: I can't say
Question 2 (short answer): What is the breed of the dog?

Condition: Question 2 will be visible only if the answer to Question 1 is "Yes".
When on Question 2, click on "Condition", then select Question 1 as conditional question and select "Yes" as conditional answer.
de.cspb-create-project-source-0:
It’s time to import your source files (images, videos, sounds, ...). The possible data sources include: Dropbox, Flickr, Amazon S3 buckets or csv file. There are particular cases for Twitter or CSLoger datasources.

You will also be able to add additional files later from the “project overview” page when the project was already created.

Note: The Project Builder is NOT copying your file, it is linking to them. So make sure they stay in the original location for the duration of the project.

Make sure you are authorized to use the data, ie. use free licensed files (Creative Commons or alike), your own files, or copyright files that you are authorized to use.

Example:
We have a list of public images in csv format, then click on “csv File”, for uploading it.
de.cspb-create-project-source-1:
Finally, before creating the project, you can check the summary. Since this point is possible to come back using the navigation routes on the top-left section and to edit whatever you consider.

Click on “CREATE!” button. To finalize the process.
de.cspb-integration-cslogger-project-type-0:
For the particular case of CSLogger project type, please click on the “CSLogger” button Select your project type as is presented on the image.

Note: The previous steps to this are similar regardless of the project type. Please check the “How to create a project” section.
de.cspb-integration-cslogger-project-type-1: CSLogger just allows the creation of a simple survey for your task protocol. Please click on “Survey”.
de.cspb-integration-cslogger-project-source:
Import your data collected by the crowdsourcing process done with the CSLogger applet already downloaded. The required files are:

  • Data file: report.csv file with metadata and responses.
  • Media files: unzipped multimedia files.

Note: if you have not yet downloaded the data, please go to admin.mindlogger.org, and follow the instructions on tools/cslogger Integration with CS Project Builder section.
de.cspb-test-and-publish-project-0:
Each project has its own page, which has two important sections. In the upper section you can find the following buttons:

  • MODIFY DRAFT: allows you to edit the current version of the project.
  • TEST IT!: by clicking on this button you can test the version that the users will see.
  • GET SHAREABLE LINK: creates a temporary link for you to share with others.
  • SUBMIT FOR PUBLICATION: send to Citizen Science Center a request to be published.

Example:
Click on “TEST IT!” button to check your project creation.
de.cspb-test-and-publish-project-1:
Few things before you go public:

  • Double check the Criteria for publication on the top of this page and make sure the project complies.
  • Please remember “GET A SHARABLE LINK” allows you to share your draft with co-workers (don’t use this link for running the project there results won’t be saved).

Ready?... “SUBMIT FOR PUBLICATION”
We will make sure your project adheres to our criteria and works, and get back to you within a few hours with approval or - if need be - additional requests.
de.cspb-test-and-publish-project-settings-0:
From the different tabs of your project’s dashboard, you access:

  • Info: overview (modify) the current description of the project.
  • Statistics overview the current statistics for your projects when are published.
  • Tasks: you can do multiple actions:
    • Import Tasks - import more source files via the provided importer
    • Task Presenter - change the protocol of your tasks.
      Note: This require coding skills.
    • Browse - check the status of each task after published.
    • Export Tasks - export tasks to JSON, CSV, or a CKAN server.
    • Task Settings - configure all aspects of tasks, including scheduler, priority, and redundancy. You can also delete tasks.
  • Settings: edit the description of the project, select project category, allow anonymous contribution.
de.about-question-1: Was ist der Citizen Science Project Builder?
de.about-answer-1: Der Citizen Science Project Builder ist ein webbasiertes Tool, mit dem Forschende, Studierende sowie Bürgerinnen und Bürger Citizen Science Projekte entwickeln und durchführen können.
de.about-question-2: Was ist ein Citizen Science Projekt?
de.about-answer-2: Bei Citizen Science Projekten arbeiten freiwillige Mitwirkende («Bürger» oder «Bürgerinnen») und Forschende zusammen, um Wissen zu generieren. Viele verschiedene Projektformen sind möglich – von der Klassifizierung von Schlangenbildern über die Transkription handschriftlicher deutscher Dialekte bis hin zum Sammeln von Wasserproben und Fotodokumentationen über Insekten und Pflanzen. Wenn Sie mehr über Citizen Science erfahren möchten, finden Sie bei {link1} auf hilfreiche Informationen (einschliesslich einer umfassenden Liste bereits existierender Projekte).
de.about-question-3: Welche Projekte können mit dem CS Project Builder entwickelt werden?
de.about-answer-3: Die Erstversion des CS Project Builder ermöglicht den Personen, die ihn nutzen, die Durchführung komplexer Datenklassifizierungen. Sie unterstützt Projekte, bei denen bereits existierende Daten von Mitwirkenden analysiert oder angereichert werden können – typischerweise grosse Bild- oder Textmengen (z. B. Satellitenfotos, Social-Media-Beiträge etc.), aber auch andere Medienformate wie Video- und Audioaufzeichnungen und gescannte Unterlagen. Im nächsten Schritt wird in das webbasierte Tool ein Tool zur Datenerfassung (Smartphone-basiert) integriert.
de.about-question-4: Was ist der Zweck des CS Project Builder?
de.about-answer-4: Der CS Project Builder erleichtert die Durchführung von CS Projekten, indem er eine Benutzeroberfläche bietet, die keine speziellen technischen Kenntnisse und bestenfalls nur wenig oder gar keine Programmierkenntnisse erfordert. Er soll die gemeinsame Entwicklung – die «Co-Creation» – von Citizen Science Projekten erleichtern, wobei mit der Durchführung einfacher Pilotprojekte begonnen wird.
de.about-answer-5: Alle, die eine Idee für ein Datenklassifizierungsprojekt haben, können ihr Projekt hier planen, solange es die Plattformkriterien erfüllt. Im nächsten Schritt bauen Sie eine Teilnehmer-Community für das Projekt auf (Kolleginnen, Freunde, Familienmitglieder und auch andere), mit deren Hilfe sich Umfang, Form und Potenzial des Projekts austesten lassen. Durch Einbindung aller Mitwirkenden in den Co-Creation-Prozess können wertvolle Informationen über Forschungsfragen, Prozesse, Daten und gegenseitigen Nutzen gewonnen werden, bevor man sich entschliesst, noch mehr Mittel in die Ausgestaltung zu investieren (d. h. bevor man ein Projekt mit eigenem graphischen Konzept entwickelt, spezifische Charakteristika erarbeitet etc. Bitte kontaktieren Sie uns, wenn Sie weitere Informationen zu dieser Option wünschen.)
de.about-answer-6: Als Vorbild für das Webinterface des CS Project Builder diente die inzwischen eingestellte Crowdcrafting platform. Die Gestaltung basiert auf dem Open Source Crowdsourcing Framework {pybossa}. Der Code ist unter der «CitizenScienceCenter» Organization auf {csgit} öffentlich verfügbar.
de.about-criteria-label1: Jeder kann ein Projekt auf der Plattform anlegen, solange folgende Kriterien beachtet werden:
de.about-criteria-list1: Thema und Zielsetzung des Projekts haben einen klaren wissenschaftlichen und/oder sozialen Bezug.
de.about-criteria-list2: Die Ziele und angestrebten Ergebnisse des Projekts sind in der Projektbeschreibung nachvollziehbar und verständlich kommuniziert.
de.about-criteria-list3: Die Projektziele sind ohne die Beteiligung der Bürgerinnen und Bürger nicht oder nur schwer zu erreichen.
de.about-criteria-list4: Das Projekt steht allen Mitwirkenden, die freiwillig teilnehmen möchten, offen.
de.about-criteria-list5: Es existiert eine einfache Möglichkeit der Kontaktaufnahme mit den Projektorganisierenden, um Feedback zu geben oder sich mündlich auszutauschen.
de.about-criteria-list6: Die Projektinhalte begünstigen keine unerlaubten Handlungen und erregen keinen Anstoss beim Projektpublikum (detailliertere Angaben hierzu finden Sie in den Terms and Conditions).
de.about-criteria-list7: Die Projektziele (Menge der benötigten Daten, Abdeckung, erforderliche Zahl der Teilnehmenden) sind angemessen und können in einem vorgegebenen Zeitraum erreicht werden.
de.about-criteria-list8: Ethische Aspekte wurden bedacht (z. B. Diversität, Inklusion, Geschlechtergleichheit), und bei Bedarf wird im Vorfeld bei der Ethikkommission der UZH/ETH eine Erlaubnis beantragt und eingeholt.
de.about-criteria-list9: Bei der Generierung der Daten durch das Projekt wird der von der Europäischen Kommission formulierte Grundsatz «as open as possible, as closed as necessary» beachtet, dem zufolge so wenige Einschränkungen wie möglich auferlegt, sensible Daten jedoch vor unbefugtem Zugriff geschützt werden sollen.
de.about-criteria-list10: Die Projektergebnisse werden in einem Open-Access-Format veröffentlicht, sofern dies legitim ist und rechtlich oder ethisch nichts dagegen spricht.
